subject: Re: [junit] written recommendation of super.setUp/tearDown ?
msgSnippet: Allan, To the best of my knowledge, JUnit 4 will automatically ensure that setup and teardown methods from superclasses are called at the appropriate time.
messageBody:
Allan,

To the best of my knowledge, JUnit 4 will automatically ensure that
setup and teardown methods from superclasses are called at the
appropriate time.

David Saff

Allan Halme wrote:

> Do we know whether JUnit 4 will be resolving this "design smell", i.e.
> will
> it no longer require subclasses of TestCase to explicitly remember to
> call
> super.setUp and super.tearDown() ?
>
> One other thing that has to be remembered, that I always initially
> forget,
> is that--at least in my test fixtures--you'll want to call super.setUp()
> _first_ in your subclass's overriding method, but you'll want to call
> super.tearDown() correspondingly _last_ in its overriding method ...
>
>
> On 27/07/05, Cedric Beust <cbeust@...> wrote:
> >
> > > From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> > > Behalf Of Russell Gold
> >
> > > On 7/26/05, Dave Brosius <dbrosius@...> wrote:
> > > > I have it in my head that the junit folks recommend always calling
> > > > super.setUp/tearDown from a user declared setUp/tearDown,
> > > even if the
> > > > JUnit test in question is directly derived from TestCase. However i
> > > > cannot find any written (web page) recommendation to so. Is
> > > this still
> > > > the case? Is there a documented recommendation some where?
> > >
> > > Even if you cannot find the page, this is definitely a good
> > > idea. If you decide at a later time to have your test case
> > > extend something besides TestCase, your invocations of
> > > super.setUp/tearDown will already be in place.
> >
> > Yup, it's the best way, but it's unfortunate that JUnit forces you to do
> > that, because having to call super is a clear design smell in OO design
> > (because if somebody subclasses your class and forget to call super, it
> > will
> > break). In short, it defeats the purpose of polymorphism.
> >
> > --
> > CÃ©dric
> > http://testng.org
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
